author: {'steamid': '76561199069064292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1691077237}
review: I've come back to this game a couple of times to beat it again and I admit it has it's flaws. With that said, it's a great game to hone your spatial skills, timing and most importantly how to look for weaknesses in video game bosses. It's strictly a boss rush game so there isn't much content outside of boss battles but that's to be partially expected in this type of game, however the pixel art was beautiful so travelling from boss to boss wasn't too much of a chore. Creative, cute and at times, brutally punishing

author: {'steamid': '76561198091305077', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1691161563}
review: Once you beat the first boss you already know everything this game could possibly throw at you. The entire game is a series of cheap, gimmicky bosses in a boss-rush format. Get hit once, die immediately. You move frustratingly slow, your attacks are frustratingly slow, and every win requires proper strategic planning. Frankly, it's a turn-off having all three of these things at once. The game at once wants your character to control in a slow, deliberate fashion, and the bosses to be frenetic, fast-paced races to the finish. If the game made your character move and attack just a *little* faster relative to the bosses, this would be a charming and challenging experience. As it is, it's just pure rage for no reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063926607', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1691148477}
review:
Imagine the worst bosses in souls series and you are fighting them in a boss rush format. This game is basically it, not the mention that you have just 1 arrow and it takes forever to pick it back up. You also have just 1 hp just like the bosses so experimentation isn't really possible if you don't want to die.

If you respect your time and money just don't buy this game.

review: this whole game is just a handful of bosses and an empty map. Each boss dies in one, sometimes two hits, making each 'battle' about finding the boss's weak spot and just trying until u get the right rng to hit it. nothing to do other than fight gimmick bosses and run around a big, empty map. If that's what you're looking for its a good time, but the game only having a few hours of content feels disappointing, luckily its cheap

author: {'steamid': '76561198254178645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1690483567}
review: So I liked the gimmick of the game where all bosses have 1 hp and you also have 1 hp so it becomes a boss rush puzzle type of game, but i tried getting into it 3 times now and every time i quit out of frustration. The boss fights are fun, but the game makes you run back through an ugly, empty world every time you die in a boss fight which is pointless and punishes you for a small movement mistake. There is nothing challenging or entertaining about running back for 30 seconds through an ugly world every time you die, and you will die a lot while you figure out timings and patterns of each boss. I quit this game 3 times out of frustration now, and every single time I did, it was not because of the hard bosses themselves but the boring walk. I do not recommend this game, not for 19$ CAD, not for 1.9$ CAD.

review:
[h1]The linked review essay is about Acid Nerve's later release [i]Death's Door[/i], but also covers the comparative strength of [i]Titan Souls[/i] near its conclusion.[/h1]

[. . .] Unlike [i]Death's Door[/i], [i]Titan Souls[/i] feels like it has a hook, a great mechanical system that serves as its focus. And that hyper focus of [i]Titan Souls[/i] on taking its barebones combat and fine-tuning every encounter around it means that itâ€™s able to excel at that one task. [. . .]

author: {'steamid': '76561197967815270', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1482288650}
review:
Titan Souls is a boss rush game that pits the tiny protagonist and their bow against gigantic enemies in pixel art arenas. 

The idea is solid - each titan is basically a puzzle, they die in one hit but so do you, so you have to identify where the weak point is and find the opening in their attack pattern. Everything is small so accuracy is tough and missing means you'll have to slowly call your singular arrow back over to you while dodging the titan's aggressive onslaught.

Gameplay is fast paced and challenging to start with but never really evolves beyond the same single mechanic. It's designed to be over as quickly as possible and while there can be a bit of a mad scramble between the start of the fight and figuring out how to deliver the killing blow there isn't much substance to the encounters other than roll-dodging for dear life. 

While my instinct is to be hard on this game I have to appreciate that it came out of a small gamejam project which was polished and tidied up for steam. It feels like a small dame dev portfolio piece, but the price absolutely reflects that so just be aware you're getting what you pay for, albeit respectably polished and good for a short single playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561199076269275', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1690294104}
review:
Dans les Souls, il y a toujours une impression de rigueur, de talent, de progression constante. Dans Shadow Of The Colossus, les colosses dÃ©gagent une impression de majestÃ©, de mÃ©lancolie, dans des environnements variÃ©s qui traduisent un lourd passÃ©. Et pour Titan Souls, qui s'inspire de ces gÃ©ants du jeu vidÃ©o, c'est vraiment dommage de ne pas retrouver ces points si iconiques.

[b][u]Points positifs :[/u][/b]
- [u]Presque jouable sur Atari :[/u] Deux boutons, deux joysticks, c'est tout ce qu'il vous faudra. Un gameplay trÃ¨s simple qui offre plus d'options qu'il n'y paraÃ®t.
- [u]Foire aux monstres :[/u] LÃ  c'est sÃ»r, il y a de la diversitÃ© niveau design. Cube, serpent ou champignon, vous serez toujours surpris par ce qui va vous massacrer.
- [u]David contre Goliath :[/u] Ces choses rÃ©sistent Ã  vos flÃ¨ches et font dix fois votre taille. Et pourtant tout comme vous, elles meurent d'un seul coup bien placÃ© ! Ce simple fait rend le jeu (parfois) trÃ¨s satisfaisant et rÃ©Ã©quilibre un peu la balance (voir ci-aprÃ¨s).
- [u]Remue-mÃ©ninges :[/u] La dimension de casse-tÃªte n'est pas anecdotique, et une telle prise de risque est Ã  saluer, d'autant qu'elle rend leu jeu plutÃ´t unique.

[b][u]Points nÃ©gatifs :[/u][/b]
- [u]Esquive la balle ! :[/u] Comme tous les boss vous tuent en un coup et sont pour la plupart assez rapides, vous n'aurez souvent pas le temps de rÃ©flÃ©chir ou faire des tests que vous serez dÃ©jÃ  mort. EmbÃªtant dans un jeu oÃ¹ la rÃ©flexion et l'expÃ©rience sont centrales.
- [u]Violence gratuite :[/u] La difficultÃ©, c'est un fait, mais Titan Souls traduit une sorte d'acharnement (non intentionnel) envers le joueur. Les boss qui continuent Ã  vous molester pendant que vous Ãªtes Ã©crasÃ© au sol, des Ã©lÃ©ments superflus qui vous pourrissent la vie (Le boss est trop simple ? Ajoutez des traÃ®nÃ©es de feu !), un compteur de morts qui n'a aucun intÃ©rÃªt... Bref, si le jeu est lÃ  vous vous sortir de votre zone de confort, c'est clairement sans bienveillance.
- [u]Souliers usÃ©s :[/u] Vous passerez probablement plus de temps Ã  courir qu'Ã  combattre. Entre la zone centrale gigantesque mais vide, l'absence de tÃ©lÃ©portation, et les dix secondes passÃ©es Ã  chaque mort pour revenir jusqu'au boss, c'est rapidement lassant. Et contrairement aux Souls qui ont un principe similaire, ici vous mourrez maximum 10 secondes aprÃ¨s avoir commencÃ© le combat, et surtout...
- [u]Tout ou rien :[/u] L'aspect Ã©nigme se rÃ©duit bien trop souvent Ã  un timing prÃ©cis ou un tir sans faille. Contrairement aux boss des jeu citÃ©s en intro dont vous ferez toujours descendre la barre de vie plus bas Ã  chaque essai, rater sur Titan Souls ne vous apport plus rien aprÃ¨s quelques essais. Vous vous contenterez de soupirer quand vous arriverez enfin Ã  vaincre ce satanÃ© boss. Surtout les quelques boss qui comportent des aspects "alÃ©atoires", qui ne vous apporteront aucun accomplissement.
- [u]Tout Ã§a pour quoi ? :[/u] Bonne question. Titan Souls n'a pas vraiment d'histoire, et le boss sont loin d'Ãªtre majestueux, et ne donnent pas l'impression d'Ãªtre d'autres Ãªtres vivants et sentients. Vous allez devoir inventer votre accomplissement aprÃ¨s les nombreux essais nÃ©cessaires Ã  chaque boss. Et si l'instant fatidique oÃ¹ l'Ã©cran se fige Ã  la mort d'un boss est vraiment classe, cela se termine par vous qui devez faire les chemin Ã  pied en sens inverse en laissant derriÃ¨re, vous lâ€™Ã©niÃ¨me statue qu'est devenue le corps du boss.

En rÃ©sumÃ©, Titan Souls est un boss rush sans vÃ©ritable histoire, dont l'aspect unique (les Ã©nigmes) se tarit souvent au profit de la chance et des mÃ©caniques. Son style de jeu nerveux amÃ¨ne malheureusement une certaine lassitude, la faute Ã  des combats trop peu engageants et de longues minutes Ã  courir dans un monde vide. Le jeu aurait sÃ»rement profitÃ© d'un mode invincible pour les amoureux de la rÃ©flexion s'il ne lui Ã©tait pas nÃ©cessaire de rallonger sa durÃ©e de vie par une difficultÃ© plus que sÃ©rieuse. 
Si vous voulez profiter d'une ambiance poÃ©tique et d'une B.O. tout aussi sympa, vous pouvez regarder Death's Door, du mÃªme dÃ©veloppeur avec le mÃªme compositeur, qui lui vaut vraiment son prix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038139937', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1689997807}
review:
This game could be great, but it tries to be Shadow of the colossus and fails horribly.
The wolrd is HUGE filled with nothingness, you just walk around trying to find the next boss.
Once you find the boss you will die over and over until you figure out how to beat it, and each time you fail you have to take the walk of shame back to the boss. No enemies, no nothing, just your time being wasted every time you die just to try again.
And last but not least, the achievements are ridiculous. Most of the achievements are challanges "kill X boss in Y seconds", "kill  the boss pulling back your arrow", etc.
If you just want to beat the game you will get an whopping 4 or 5 achievements out of 27.
You are not Dark Souls, you are not Shadow of the Colossus. Just let us try the boss again instantly and cut out the huge world, no one cares about it, seriously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108144738', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1689110684}
review:
PRO: Stile, difficile, gameplay unico, breve
CONTRO: Poco memorabile, nessuna trama
VOTO: 8/10

---------------------------------------------------------

Nonostante sia degli stessi autori di Death's Door, che ho amato, fino a non molto tempo fa non mi sarei neanche immaginato di poter dare una chance a un titolo come Titan Souls ma invece eccomi qui.

La prima cosa che salta all'occhio Ã¨ la pixel art eccezionale, con ambientazioni pazzesche e un buon level design, purtroppo sfruttato solo negli spostamenti in quanto privo di nemici, enigmi o collezionabili. La qualitÃ  del comparto tecnico si estende anche alle animazioni molto fluide e alla buona, seppur non troppo memorabile, colonna sonora. Ci tengo inoltre a far notare come i testi siano in italiano, nonostante Steam dichiari il contrario.

Peccato invece per la storia, che di fatto Ã¨ assente ad eccezione di una breve frase pronunciata da un boss segreto. Personalmente questo Ã¨ un aspetto a cui do molto peso e avrei gradito anche solo un minimo di contestualizzazione delle azioni, che invece rimangono solo fine a sÃ© stesse nonostante la grande epicitÃ .

In ogni caso Ã¨ ovviamente il gameplay ad essere il fulcro della produzione e ne Ã¨ forse anche l'elemento di maggior pregio. Titan Souls consiste in un boss rush in cui bisogna sconfiggere 19 titani (diversi dei quali opzionali o segreti, piÃ¹ uno presente solo nel New Game + e uno sbloccabile tramite un workaround) nell'ordine che si preferisce (eccetto in alcuni casi), essendo ognuno di essi confinato in una singola arena accessibile dal mondo di gioco, che assume quindi la funzione di hub. Tutti i nemici sono diversi per meccaniche e aspetto, pur non risultando mai iconici come quelli di Death's Door (anche se ce n'Ã¨ uno molto simile).

La peculiaritÃ  di questo titolo Ã¨ che si uccide o muore con solo un colpo e si dispone solo di un arco e una freccia. Quest'ultima puÃ² essere caricata a piacere (i colpi potenti richiedono perÃ² molto tempo per essere eseguiti) e poi recuperata passandoci sopra oppure richiamandola a sÃ© a distanza, permettendole quindi di infliggere danni anche durante il ritorno.

Non Ã¨ tuttavia sempre vero che basti un colpo per sconfiggere i boss in quanto diversi di questi necessitano di una "preparazione" per esporne il punto debole (anche se spesso non richiedono attacchi diretti). Ho notato inoltre come questi possano essere divisi in due categorie: da una parte ci sono nemici semplici da leggere e schivare ma che non si capisce come sconfiggere, dall'altra ce ne sono alcuni di cui Ã¨ subito palese il funzionamento ma che sono letali.

Si tratta infatti di un gioco molto difficile, che sono tuttavia riuscito a completare al 100% in circa 4 ore, nonostante le ben 266 morti all'attivo. A peggiorare la situazione c'Ã¨ anche una prospettiva non sempre chiarissima, in particolare per quanto riguarda la profonditÃ  e la distanza dal terreno degli oggetti che cadono, gestita solo con le ombre.

In conclusione, Titan Souls Ã¨ un'opera impegnativa ma appagante, grazie ad uno stile eccezionale e ad un game design unico. Peccato solo per l'assenza di una trama a giustificare le azioni, che rimangono quindi limitate ad una pura sfida tecnica. La sua brevitÃ  e la divisione in arene separate lo rendono perfetto come passatempo estivo, oppure come intermezzo di un titolo piÃ¹ grande.

VOTO: 8/10

review:
Nun ja, wer es geil findet ausschlieÃŸlich Bosse zu besiegen die auf dem One Hit=Kill Prinzip basieren hat mit dem spiel sicherlich viel spaÃŸ, um fair zu sein haben alle Bosse auch nur ein Leben wie eben der Spieler, was sich aber dennoch nach verschwendeten Potenzial anfÃ¼hlt, da sich die Bosse nicht mit unterschiedlichen Angriffsmuster erweitern/entwickeln. Nach jedem Tod muss man Ã¼brigens wieder den ganzen Weg zum Boss laufen (circa 10-20 Sekunden pro Tod), was auf Dauer sehr zeitintensiv sein wird. 

Dass das Spiel ein Soulslike ist war vorher klar, aber bei einem angeblichen Action-Adventure habe ich mir auch RÃ¤tsel und Story gewÃ¼nscht, dies sucht man hier vergeblich, sodass es nur ein Soulslike mit Action Elementen ist.

FÃ¼r eine Retro/Pixelart-Spiel kann man schon mehr erwarten. Das Spiel macht so ziemlich alles falsch, was z.B Cuphead (ebensfall sehr schwierig, aber faire bosse wenn man die angriffsmuster lernt) richtig macht. Es fÃ¼hlt sich einfach verschwendet und billig an.

Und dass es noch einen Hardcore Mode (was jeden Boss doppelt so schwer macht), sowie den Iron Man Mode gibt, wo man nur ein Leben hat lÃ¤sst es noch lÃ¤cherlicher, unfairer und repetetiver wirken wenn man alle achievements haben mÃ¶chte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198200975898', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1689266440}
review:
This game is one or two MINOR tweaks from being an absolutely amazing time, but the combination of handicaps in this game against you just makes it feel unbalanced and unfun for ME. Your only attack being in MY opinion bad makes the whole game not feel great to begin with. The fact you have to charge your shot everytime, your character is an absolute moron and only has 1 arrow so you have to either run/roll to your 1 arrow everytime you shoot the damn thing or call it slowly and die waiting. I'm not saying make the game super easy, just balance 1 of the few things that make it for me unbearable to play.  

Either slow enemies by like 1/6th (not my preferred fix), have more than 1 arrow, have the arrow come back immediately OR not require super precise shooting with a half second to look, aim and shoot (half second combined) without a proper precise tool. This is a game that feels like it becomes much easier if you can aim with a mouse and actually hit what you are trying to instead of going for the closest general area and having to die 12 times because the shot barely missed.

This game annoys me a lot because I know if you adjusted like one thing in a more balanced way I'd LOVE it, but as is. I can't play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272019210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1688758624}
review: This game is hard af until you figure out the gimmicks. Every boss only takes 1 or 2 hits to kill but they have unique attack patterns with very short windows to hit their weak spot. You also move very slow relative to boss attacks and have ZERO Invincibility frames. Overall the game is pretty unique and can be fun for a while but do get ready to rage hard. Only downside is it's pretty short. I'd say 50% sale price is worth it. I would definitely not pay $15 for a game from 2015 That also has so little content, but thats just my opinion. Again not bad, but lacking content for the price.

review: Love this game, I grew up on SNES it has that look, but obviously plays differently. Its a shorter game, but there is replay value in both achievements and new modes unlocked. I had free access for years through PS+, I have since built a PC and gave up that subscription, and was happy to pay (on sale) for this game I had already played through. Bosses are varied in their mechanics, fun to discover their weak spots and exploit them. Recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198450345569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 317, 'playtime_forever': 1381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1381, 'last_played': 1688003527}
review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

titan souls is a indie souls-like action-adventure game featuring 2D pixel graphics that was developed by acid nerve and published by devolver digital. acid nerve us a two-person team from manchester, UK and titan souls was their debut game. it was originally created for the ludum dare game jam, but over the course of the next 6 months, it was ported from adobe flash to a new engine, which enhanced graphic capabilities and improved performance, with more titan fights being added as well over the course of development. it was first revealed by devolver digital in june 2014 at E3. in march 2015, devolver revealed the game would release in april 2015. on april 14th 2015, titan souls was released on PC, PS4, and the PS vita. a android port was later released in june 2015. 

titan souls is a strategic top-down action-adventure where you only can take one hit before dying. the bosses also only can take one hit, but they have specific scenarios that need to be met in order to be defeated. you also only have one arrow, and you need to retrieve it after shooting it. titan souls has been cited as an early example of a souls-like game, but i think it has enough to set it apart. it has simple controls, and a large variety of boss fights, as well as featuring high amounts of replay-ability. there's a good degree of difficulty, which will inevitably lead toa  lot of deaths. i enjoyed the difficulty, as it felt very rewarding to get hard achievements or taking down a memorably hard boss with a really weird mechanic that took me forever to figure out how to kill. i could see some people complaining that the controls are overly simplistic, or that the game's boss battles are extremely repetitive, but i genuinely had a lot of fun.

titan souls is only $14.99 full price, with 90% off sales coming repeatedly marking it down to only $1.49 which is a really great price. this is now the sixth devolver digital game i've completed, having previously completed hotline miami (2012), gods will be watching, expendabros, sigils of elohim, the talos principle (2014). as of june 2023, i have seven more devolver games still to complete now, with potentially more to add to those seven should i purchase more of their amazing game catalogue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139363901', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1687786098}
review:
Just because i's hard, does not mean it's going to be fun.
While fun to look at, the bosses often only have 2-3 moves because there are so many.
The mechanics, again, while simple, seem to remain exactly the same, never evolving. You as a player need to evolve.

Having only the cardinal directions limits the shooting, but doesn't affect the arrow returning, meaning there is a huge trade-off. The returning arrow mechanics is honestly just unfun, but when it hits just right, the small dopamine hit is pretty good.

I'm personally un-invested as well. I'm just a nameless shmuck with a bow and arrow.

If you're looking for the boss-rush-esque thing it has going on, can deal with dying and running back to the boss being your most of your playtime, you're in a great place.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090938080', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1638484227}
review:
Titan Souls is a game where every encounter with the bosses becomes a high-stakes battle of precision and strategy. The "1 shot 1 kill" mechanics add an exhilarating twist to the gameplay, especially when you consider that these bosses require a single well-placed shot to defeat. It's an incredibly satisfying feeling to take down these formidable foes in such a challenging manner.

Each boss in Titan Souls possesses unique mechanics that not only test your skills but also provide a decent level of difficulty. Overcoming their various strategies and patterns requires careful observation and strategic thinking.

The game provides an enticing gameplay experience, but just know that some achievements make playing the game literal hell, so if you want to 100% the game, please take note of this. 

The game also has a great visual aesthetic. The art style and attention to detail bring the bosses and environments to life, enhancing the overall immersion and adding an extra layer of enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198235062292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1687326594}
review:
Amazing game, well designed, great art, tight control. Has a few glaring flaws which make me not want to recommend this. 

1. No option to rebind controls. God forbid you play on PC this uses one of the worst control schemes to exist : Arrow Keys and Z X
2. EXCRUCIATINGLY LONG RESPAWNS. If you die to an enemy (and you will die, often) the time taken to get back in the fight is frustrating and it gets worse as you progress. This is not a game meant for normal people, if you have a LOT of patience or too much skill to 1 try each boss, go for it. Otherwise I would not recommend this title even though I've enjoyed it and will probably come back to it again and again till I beat it. 

In the current build it is [b]broken on SteamDeck[/b], killing a boss force quits the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045603400', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1686083634}
review:
Una de las principales preocupaciones que encontrÃ© en Titan Souls fue el tiempo que tardan los puntos de reapariciÃ³n, lo cual puede resultar frustrante. En algunos casos, te ves obligado a recorrer la mitad del mapa para enfrentarte nuevamente al jefe al que estÃ¡s intentando vencer. Esta mecÃ¡nica puede llevar a una sensaciÃ³n de repeticiÃ³n innecesaria y prolongar la duraciÃ³n del juego mÃ¡s de lo deseado.

Otra cuestiÃ³n a tener en cuenta es que, desafortunadamente, la mitad de los jefes del juego no resultan divertidos de enfrentar. Esto puede afectar negativamente la experiencia general, ya que los encuentros con los jefes son una parte fundamental del juego.

AdemÃ¡s, jugar con teclado puede ser limitante, especialmente debido a la falta de opciones de direcciÃ³n clara. Hubiera sido preferible que el personaje pudiera apuntar con el mouse, lo que permitirÃ­a una jugabilidad mÃ¡s fluida y una experiencia de calidad similar a la de jugar con un control.

En resumen, Titan Souls tiene algunos aspectos problemÃ¡ticos que afectan su disfrute. Los largos tiempos para volver a pelear con los jefes, la falta de diversiÃ³n en algunos de sus bosses y las limitaciones al jugar con teclado.

author: {'steamid': '76561199002426288', 'num_games_owned': 376, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1801, 'last_played': 1648488480}
review:
Very short and charming game, and a must-play if you enjoy boss rushes, or the analytic trial and error process of dark souls bosses (note that there isn't much else in the game besides this, so at least be ok with those). The pixel art is pretty charming, and although there isn't much story the game holds a specific theme and feel very well. Each boss feels original and well-designed, and there is a nice problem-solving loop you go through when dealing with each new challenge.

Be fairly warned though, it can be *frustratingly* challenging, so if that's not your cup of tea then this won't be for you. I also think the game is fairly pricey for the amount of content in it (although go ahead if you want to support the devs' great work), but the game often gets a whopping 90% discount, so just wait for one of those to grab it, because at the discounted price its 1000% worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199076721007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1702029327}
review: The game isn't what you expect when you hear soul-like. in this game you one-shot bosses if you hit them in their weak spot so they turn out either too easy or too hard and frustrating. if told more detailed about the fights, you go to fight a boss you die instantly because you didn't know what to expect, die a few more times trying to memorize his attacks and figure out where to shoot (bec the bosses are invinceble exept for their weak spots and sometimes the shield thats protecting the weak spot) and then you just realize how little progression that gave you and that you didn't learn any useful skills or knowlege to use aganist the next bosses. also forgot to mention, you'll have to walk to the boss area for 5-10 seconds every time you die (one hit) while the fights fully last at most a few minutes, so in the end this whole list makes the game very boring, frustrating and just not enjoyable.

To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable TITAN.exe on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [âœ“].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044518882', 'num_games_owned': 543, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1684539801}
review:
You walk the first time and learn one trick of this particular boss. "oh so the boss does this, ok!"
You walk the second time and learn that the pillar which you are hiding behind can be pierced by the enemy's weapon.
You walk the third time and discovers that the boss also have a secondary weapon...
You walk the fourth time and manage to get a shot, but you have no precise aim since the game is a twin-stick shooter and mouse isn't supported...
You walk the fifth time...
Seems to me that it tried to do something similar to Shadow of the Colossus, but SotC compensate the lonely walking by being amazingly beautiful, the first of it's kind, and having no one-hit deaths so you can manage to learn about the boss without unnecessary walking every single mistake.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082613902', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1684518515}
review:
Fun little boss-focused game. The full price is a little steep for how simple and short it is, but I got it for like 4 euros which was more than fine.
My only complains would be that rolling into stairs bounce you off, it might make sense physically but is annoying as fuck, all the boss stages are flat so this only affects traversing anyway.
The 2nd small complaint would be the â€œfinalâ€ boss, next to all previous bosses which felt well designed, interesting, sometimes even innovative, the â€œfinalâ€ one was just spam this move and die over and over again until the enemy RNG is suiting and then shoot him. I even looked online whether thereâ€™s something more to his movements that I missed, but nope all the guides were super short/fast so my brute force solution was indeed correct.
The Truth boss on the other hand was a nice surprise, probably the best in the game.

You can recognize some of the gameplay concepts, ideas and soundtrack melodies brewing here, that were later reused and and improved in Death's Door. If you havenâ€™t played Death's Door then I highly recommend starting with that. It's an objectively far better game, longer, with a proper story, actual gameplay in between bosses etc.

Technical notes:
- runs well on Steam Deck
- getting 100% achievements is hard and requires heavy replaying

review: Jogo maravilhoso, recomendo muito. Hoje em dia compensa mais pegar na promoÃ§Ã£o, Ã© um jogo bem curtinho mas com vÃ¡rias mecÃ¢nicas diferentes pra cada boss, alÃ©m de ter um grÃ¡fico muito lindo e uma trilha sonora espetacular. Paguei uns 6 reais na promoÃ§Ã£o, vale muito a pena :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030451917', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 364, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1682725241}
review:
EZ GAME LUL

Real talk though, it was a pretty easy game. Finished all bosses in 5hrs (Truth Ending). 

Personally think it's mis-tagged as a souls-like because there's nothing souls-like about it. I think you'll enjoy it much more if you approach the game as a puzzle boss rush. All the bosses have a weak point where it only takes one hit to beat, just have to figure out each one's gimmick of how/when to hit it.

I will say I did have few complaints but overall really not a bad game. For sure, it's super tedious running back each attempt even if it is a short distance. Game can definitely benefit from a fast-retry. Some of the bosses were just dumb and obnoxious, but still was satisfying most of the time getting the dub.

Obviously as with any game on Steam, you should really get it on sale especially since it gets dirt cheap. I think it was free in the store page one day so I nabbed it but it was entertaining enough to recommend. I don't see how the additional modes you unlock after beating the game would be fun at all so I didn't play them LOL but initial play-through was fine.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995220422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 334, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1684067057}
review:
The fights are short and often frustrating, swiftly killing you without notice until you learn through dying how to handle each fight. 

There's very little to this short game, so don't expect to get much mileage out of it.

However you slice it though, it gives the incorrect input prompts for a dualshock controller, and that always means a negative review from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087697597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1684027022}
review:
If you donâ€™t have lighting fast reflexes this is a game where you will spend more time respawning and running to the boss rooms than in the actual fights.

The gameâ€™s main gimmick is an arrow which you must shoot and then call back to you. Both the shooting and the call back can hit the bosses. 
For most bosses youâ€™ll need to aim extremely precisely on a controller (the game is unplayable on a keyboard because you canâ€™t aim with the mouse) on an extremely small timeframe because you will constantly be dodging.

If you are not into rage games, this game is not for you. 
To give you an idea of the difficulty, as of the time of writing this, despite it being a short game, looking at the steam achievements only 15,9% of the players have managed to get to the final boss area, while over 50% had finished the 1st area.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991189097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1683776962}
review:
I was torn, but I chose not to recommend it for two reasons:

1) The respawn time is just too long, especially when combined with the walkback.
2) The final boss feels unfair.

To be clear, I beat the whole thing, and I can see why people might love this game. The mechanics are, overall, well done, and it's incredibly challenging. But the tedium of waiting between tries at the bosses really kills the pace, and that, coupled with how *ridiculous* the final boss is... just not a game I will come back to. :-/

author: {'steamid': '76561198308801538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1682969338}
review:
Atmosfera: 3/5
Idea: 4/5
Realizzazione: 2/5

Recensione difficile, gioco carino ma un po' insipido. Comparto artistico buono, musiche rilassanti, ambientazioni godibili da esplorare ma completamente vuote. Trama inesistente, c'Ã¨ giusto un filo di lore non particolarmente impegnata. Ottima l'idea di combattere solo boss, ho iniziato il gioco per quello, non so cosa mi aspettassi ma il risultato non mi ha detto granchÃ©. Non c'Ã¨ progressione, non ci sono potenziamenti, non ci sono armi, non c'Ã¨ nulla, solo noi con una freccia e i boss, one shot per one shot. Che come idea sarebbe stata anche una gran figata se non fosse stata ridotta ad un pizzico di riflessi a contorno di una non indifferente dose di fortuna. Cerca il punto debole del boss nel caos, non farti spiaccicare, non farti sfiorare neanche un pixel, cerca di azzeccare direzione e tempismo della freccia verso la palla rosa del boss, fine, molto trial and error. Caricamenti e tempi di respawn lunghi un secolo e una corsa molto lenta tra checkpoint e boss. Nulla piÃ¹, Ã¨ questa la difficoltÃ . Direi che non basta far morire di continuo e avere boss "difficili" per essere ispirati ai Souls. Boh, consigliato se fortemente scontato, ma se c'Ã¨ una demo provate prima quella.

Che poi si gioca letteralmente con due tasti ma non ce li si puÃ² impostare e il mouse non Ã¨ contemplato... relativo eh, but why?

author: {'steamid': '76561198029610672', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1683656107}
review:
That's crazy, man, a perfect distillation of everything I dislike about Soulsborne gameplay (go in, lose to unknown mechanic, die, slowly respawn and walk all the way back, do it on repeat until all unknown abilities become known and also a mechanically successful fight occurs) combined with a respawn-and-return charade that take 10 times as long as the boss fights, win or lose?  Can't believe I don't enjoy this.  

People who get satisfaction or some sense of completion out of beating hard Souls bosses will love this as it does away with all the pretense of mook encounters and grinding - although not the tedious walks back - but if you don't enjoy that gameplay loop in the first place, prepare for a more agonizing and aggravating version of it here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117372957', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 289, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1683490199}
review:
Personally, I found the difficulty level just right. 


I managed to beat the game in less than 2 hours, died about 100 times, and it was a highly enjoyable and distinct experience. Those who complain are either easily frustrated, bad at the game, overreacting, or all of the above. Just dodge for about 30 seconds and land a single hit on the boss. Also, the short walk (5-10 seconds) back to the boss after dying is not noticeably tedious.


Overall, it's a fun and unique game that offers a satisfying challenge without being excessively punishing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198391600708', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1685434487}
review:
In this game you play as a character who only has a bow and arrow to his name. This on the other hand can be used in many different ways. A slight twist to the usual games is that the bosses were one hit one kill, which gave a feeling of equality as well. I was a fan of the difficulty and never found it hard enough for it to make me want to quit.

The atmosphere in this game was spectactular. The art that creates the world, the music playing in the background and the enemies that create the world all contributed to a fantastic game experience.

I really enjoyed every bit of this game and definitely reccomend it if you're looking for a short and challenging adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143257798', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1683186457}
review:
Feels like a foundation for something really good, but all the little details are missing.
Respawn takes 15 seconds if you include walking
the environment is plain and flat (so far), Walking is boring
bosses AND you are 1-hit kill, which means you die a bunch by necessity then instantly kill the boss when you learnt it which feels weirdly unsatisfying.
You can only aim in cardinal directions in keyboard which is...why? Everything i fought so far needed good accuracy that I don't have due to bad controls. It doesn't feel like my fault, but the game's

The weird thing is that all of those things can be fixed quite easily, make me respawn in front of the arena, Spice up the map, Make it so beating a boss gives you a 1-hit shield for 3 lives, And most importantly let me rotate my aim

author: {'steamid': '76561198016991944', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1683089178}
review:
TLDR:
This game is cute for lack of a better word to encompass most of it, music is stellar, gameplay is for the most part fun save for a few enemies requiring very precise timing/aim, story is almost nonexistent. Worth the full price and fun 4.5 hours I got out of it.

The basic idea of "you have one arrow, every boss dies on "one hit" and so do you" is a fun gimmick on paper however it becomes annoying as all hell when you have bosses that require you to shoot once to open up their weaknesses and then call the arrow back, pull the bowstring, AIM that shit correctly and shoot at a VERY specific weak point all in the span of like A SECOND. Knight Elhanan is the most egregious example of this. While some of the boss' puzzles are easy to understand as "oh hit that part" some others make you go ??? what do I do here ???, Onyxia has a big shinning purple tail but it is hard to hit so it makes you wonder if you're even SUPPOSED to hit it or if you're meant to do something with the side crystals/your arrow/the icebergs/etc when it REALLY was "just shoot it".

The game suffers a lot from the walk back between a boss and the respawn point, even if walking back is just 10 seconds it makes you go "wish I was just there already". If I am too benevolent I can think the devs wanted to give the player a few seconds to cool off their brains on the way to the boss but a part of me feels like it ended up being more annoying than helpful as it would take the "momentum" out of you.

I enjoyed the walk from one area to the next, it is downright criminal how good the soundtrack for the game is, almost like it is too good for this game. Not that this is a bad game but the soundtrack being such top shelf stuff is almost jarring.

Plot-wise it is OK, just a ginormous OK. The plot is nearly non-existent as you just start the game and start blasting, all bosses have weird glyphs instead of names unless you play through the game wise but unless you're into the harder challenge of NG+ (I'm not) you would never find out their names unless you looked it up on a wiki and honestly why WOULD you care for their names, you meet some of them for less than 30 seconds before moving to the next one, their impact on your is almost proportional to how long you were trying to beat them.

I think my favorite joke/bit/whatever from the game is how, every time you beat a Titan and consume their soul there's this grandiose animation of you eating the soul and becoming a whole ass being of light for a split second until your character stops levitating and goes back to just being a lil' guy, the super titan soul changing NOTHING in you looks/gameplay wise. I found it funny at least. That and the fact that if you try to roll UP stairs your character just FLOPS/bumps into the stairs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030978836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1683074608}
review:
A surprisingly fun, if simple, boss-rush game that is somewhat reminiscent of Dark Souls. But I would describe Titan Souls more as an action-based puzzler. You die in one hit but so does the boss, and you've got a single reusable arrow to kill the boss with. When you get into the rhythm of feeling out the boss' moveset and learning their patterns, it becomes a somewhat zen-like experience as patience becomes your best strategy.

Due to the nature of the game mechanics, bosses can range from surprisingly easy to frustratingly difficult depending on how quickly you can figure out the ideal way to kill them. Most bosses felt fair and understandable, with my only complaint being the [spoiler]image[/spoiler] boss which had so many mechanics going on (and a misleading sound cue) that I had to look up how to find the weakspot. I also seemed to be able to cheese two of the bosses due to them being unable to reach me when I stayed at the south end of their rooms, which was unfortunate. For the most part though it was satisfying learning how to properly defeat each boss.

The reviewers complaining about the runbacks to the boss rooms are blowing things out of proportion in my opinion. This is nowhere near Dark Souls levels of runback. The longest one is maybe 20 seconds with most of them being around 5, and you don't have to deal with the annoyances of dodging enemies and losing resources on the way there. Plus the death and revive animations are nice and short. I never felt frustrated playing this game, and I get fucking livid at some of the Dark Souls runbacks.

Speaking of Dark Souls comparisons, the game unfortunately doesn't let you pause. Please let us pause our games, developers. I don't understand this decision.

Would I buy the game for $15? Probably not, but the game goes on DEEP sales to about $1.50, and for that it's a steal.

[h1]My Rating: 3/5[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198087000489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1682977311}
review:
Whilst the bossfights are not badly designed, being instantly killed by them is not fun if you cannot immediately restart the bossfight, having to walk back from the savepoint becomes very tedious. The true ending battle is among the best in the game, in part because it automatically restarts the fight. I also find that the controls annoy me, having both sprint and roll on the same key sucks, I want to sprint but not roll, please. 

The way this game handles fullscreen, at least on Windows, feels very crappy. Switching to FS is slow and messes with the scale of your desktop (which screws up the window sizes of other apps you have open), and for the higher resolutions it fails to center correctly on my computer, forcing me to play on lower res. 

The idea of the game is not bad, there's just a lot of implementation details that make it a chore to play. I got this game for 2 euros at 90% off so I really shouldn't complain, but at full price of 20 euros I wouldn't say it's worth it.

The music is good, and the graphics are nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122812272', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1682749249}
review:
After 7 years, 3 saves and 411 deaths, i finally beat the titan soul.

What did it cost?
[b]Everything[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561199103590118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1710875634}
review: This thing is a childhood favorite of mine. When i was really little my parents bought it for me to play because i wanted it for the cool idea of fighting titans, and I was immediately in love. Everything from the beautiful pixel graphics, to the fights which i was terrible at winning, to the art mosaics and lore that I never did understand. I just got it on sale and I love it all over again, especially the music - the beautiful, soothing melodies and awesome, empowering boss music alike. While i's by no means my favorite game ever, it definitely holds a special place in my heart that I 110% think that it has earned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093409026', 'num_games_owned': 476, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1682712054}
review:
Really hard but really good!
I really like the whole "everyone dies in one hit" premise. It does it in a way where every boss is difficult, but balanced to your power aswell.
Even for a short game, the on-sale price is is steal.
I highly recommend the game

author: {'steamid': '76561198383792242', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1681849632}
review:
The game forces you to play by the rules of the bosses with only like 2 of the few having obvious tricks around their fight, unlike games like dark souls where you decide what to do and when to do it. This game doesn't care about creating a strategy, it just hopes that you find out the only strategy there is to beat the boss and do it.

There is little to no room for error and the boss runs are just dumb, they litterally have no reason to exist and the "puzzles" are a waste of time. The designs of most bosses were also just lame or mid. They also either die within a minute of trying or you spend over 10 minutes to beat one. The difficulty is very wonky and all around a mess.

The game overall has nice graphics though and of whatever sound there was, it was good. I wouldn't even spend 5 bucks to buy this game, there is so much better elsewhere. You can get so many better games for 15 bucks or less.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989062725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1681584480}
review:
Really fun boss rush game! All in all pretty short, took me under 3 hours to beat all bosses and get the true ending, so keep that in mind when considering purchasing this game. There are a ton more achievements I can unlock for taking down bosses in special ways or playing Hard/Iron mode, but I've had this game for a long time and I'm satisfied just getting the True ending.

Super simple mechanics: you have one button that dodges (or runs if you hold it) and the other button shoots a single arrow and calls the arrow back to you when you hold the button. You die in one hit, the bosses are punishing but ALSO die in one hit, so once you learn their patterns and finally make that blow, it is incredibly satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025282636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1681515852}
review:
This game was an exercise in frustration. I really liked the concept of one-hit kills against bosses, and I absolutely loved the atmosphereâ€”the moody soundtrack and desolate pixel world were really working for meâ€”but I couldn't bring myself to enjoy it.

The fights didn't seem well-matched to the character speed or abilities, and in some cases the mechanics were just wonky: at one point I beat a boss entirely by fluke. Exploring the (very small) world was fun, but what was NOT fun was walking back to each boss a dozen or more times rather than being able to just start the fight again. Some of the boss-puzzle solutions were pretty obtuse as well, and by the end I was just looking forward to finishing so I could write this review and put the game behind me.

Don't get me started on the final boss either, which was a real disappointment and seemed to have more to do with luck than anything. Finishing everything unlocked some new aspects of game lore for me, and that's usually what I'm looking for in my games, but I won't ever see it because the idea of playing this again is too much.

The game is mercifully shortâ€”I took about five hours, but most folks take less than thatâ€”but in no way worth the price tag at any less than a 75% discount, even if you enjoy this sort of thing. Go for this if you want a punishing challenge for an afternoon and no longer than that, but otherwise there are much better options out there for the mix of moody atmosphere and frantic combat.

This would be a good experience if not for all the parts that make it a game. 4/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968658621', 'num_games_owned': 997, 'num_reviews': 461, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1680194111}
review:
Boss rush style game.  You need to work out each bosses attack patterns and fire your 1 arrow at its weak spot, which can be tricky to find.  You die in 1 hit as well.   It's very satisfying when you work out what you need to do and make that shot.

Very short.  Grab it when its on sale for $2.

It's surprisingly fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198315237893', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1673220310}
review:
[i]Originally posted on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/titan-souls/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

This is sort of like a bite-sized 2D version of Shadow of the Colossus. (Despite what the name may lead you to think, it doesnâ€™t actually have much similarity to Dark Souls.) You play as a tiny human fighting massive monsters, with some environmental storytelling hinting at surrounding context.

Hereâ€™s the most notable about this game: You only have one hit, but [i]so do the bosses[/i]. One hit to their weak point and thatâ€™s it, youâ€™re done. This has blown my mind in regards to how I think about game design and game challenges, and Iâ€™m going to vomit those thoughts at you now.

Caveat: there are a few twists on this rule, like some bosses that require additional hits to expose their weak points, but all the fights can be finished very quickly if you know what youâ€™re doing. I actually managed to get an achievement for killing a boss in under 10 seconds without even trying for it! This stuck out to me because most video game boss fights, even the more puzzle-y ones, are protracted slugfests that require you to strike the bossâ€™ weak point many times.

Having that stripped away made me wonderâ€¦ why? What does it add, actually? Once youâ€™ve figured out how to hit the boss once, then unless the fight meaningfully changes afterwards, youâ€™ve basically already won. The rest is just padding. (And I must say, it also does a lot more to respect the playerâ€™s time â€” if you get splatted midway, you havenâ€™t actually lost any progress, as opposed to if the boss had a massive healthbar.) I suppose you could argue you have to do it multiple times to prove itâ€™s not a fluke, but I find that a pretty weak argument. It was actually exciting to win several titan battles through lucky shots I just kinda hoped and prayed for.

Moreover, the game proves that doing this doesnâ€™t require sacrificing challenge. The boss fights are all incredibly engaging, and extremely difficult despite how quickly you can win them. Despite usually having an obvious weak point, the bosses are actually very good at protecting them â€” you have extremely small windows to hit them, and their vulnerable states feel like realistic tactical slip-ups rather than a video game holding your hand. For example: One of the early bosses is one of those statues with detached fists that fly around to smash you, typical video game boss design. It has a huge glowing weak spot on its chestâ€¦ but it actually uses those giant stone fists to cover its weak spot, so you canâ€™t just take free potshots. The only way to beat it is to trick it into attacking you with both fists at once, then attack it in the split-second before it can retract its fist to cover itself again. Thatâ€™s exactly the kind of genuine, split-second mistake people make in real battles, and I felt like a real tactical genius when I actually pulled it off. If that were a Zelda boss, it would leave both its fists idle for several seconds to give you a nice leisurely window to shoot it (if it bothered to do the guarding trick at all), but youâ€™d have to shoot it like ten times. This equitable health model makes every battle genuinely tense, because the slightest mistake can mean sudden death for either side. It is, I think, the kind of tone Sekiro was trying to shoot for.

Of course, by trimming all the fat the game does end up very lean â€” I beat every boss, including the secret bonus boss, in under 4 hours. But those were a really great 4 hours, and the game has perhaps the highest satisfaction-to-playtime ratio Iâ€™ve experienced. This is a game that every action game designer should study, and ask themselves if they really need to include all that padding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276201596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1681126591}
review:
Oh look, a 'controller recommended'! that's unusual, I'm not familiar with controllers though so keyboard and mouse should be fine right?
Alright, I sort of get it, not like I have controllers but I assume the controls are the same, aiming requires you to try moving in a direction while in aiming mode, and a mouse can't do that without having a massive advantage over controllers, but seriously, limiting movement and more importantly aiming to 8 directions when the weak point you're aiming for can move around freely should not be the alternative to controllers.

That aside, the boss fights feels amazing! Fighting against massive titans, running around finding it's weak point and shooting it is really exciting! unfortunately, there's a lot of downtime, death does a 5s fade to/from black, sets you back anywhere from 5-12s away from the arena, the path there feels awkward sometimes, climbing and going up the stairs is painfully slow compared to rolling on a flat plane. all for a 10s attempt. One of the most enjoying fights were the very first slime boss which is the only boss that requires you to shoot multiple times and the most unpredictable boss, wish there was more like it.

As for difficulty, the normal mode is perfect in my opinion, it takes roughly 5-10 tries to get your strategies down, and I have that much patience, I do hate a few of the bosses, though that will be spared on the very last paragraph. I will share my general feelings on those bosses here though : They don't feel hard, just annoying.

Genuinely, it is a nice experience, if its already in your library you should definitely try. as I got it when it was free I can't say much about the price. But I still want to vent. The next chunk of text are spoilers of mid to final bosses

[spoiler] One of the biggest offender of the first complain are the knight boss, not only do you need to shoot a fast moving weak point, you also need to hope that the actual knight is in one of 8 directions when the arrow is hittable, the fight itself isn't even hard to survive. The soul boss shared the same problem, with a smaller and a more confusing weak point. Speaking of weak point, the ring boss also have that issue, as it was never established that spinning very fast makes it invulnerable, and the window of it not spinning was so small that I overlooked that it's a different vulnerable state. The new game+'s hard mode made this problem a lot worse, also making more bosses feels annoying. the only constant is the first slime boss feeling really good to fight and beat. [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198440407237', 'num_games_owned': 708, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1680822426}
review: The most painfully boring and terribly designed game I've ever played ever. This game is not just boring, it's also extremely frustrating and drains your life force with every minute that you play. I got zero enjoyement from this. The game expects you to fight titans (bosses). In order to beat a boss you need to find his weak point,  if you hit the weak point the boss dies, if the boss hits you then you die. One hit is all that's needed, I like the concept HOWEVER. That weak spot has a really scuffed hitbox you need a near perfect shot to hit it. Which is really frustrating especially when the game forces you to play with a controller because yes this game doesn't have proper keyboard and mouse controls. But that's assuming that you know how to kill the boss, most of the gameplay consists of you being confused and not knowing what to do and the scuffed hitboxes are just the cherry on the top. You will try different ways to kill the boss but you have no way of knowing which way is the correct one because once you try and fail something you will always doubt the game, "was it just the wrong way to fight this boss or did I just miss because of the hitbox ?". Not knowing what to do + Not being able to execute what you want to do because of the hitbox / controls problem absolutely ruins the game. There is also another element of gamelay that makes playing this extremely frustrating and it's the stupid checkpoints. Each time you die you return to the checkpoint in the center of the area. So 1/3 of your time playing this game will be just you running back to the boss that killed you. And just so you know the respawning animation is slow. The game punishes your death with boring walks. I forced myself to reach the final boss (the secret one) and I dropped the game. My mental health has deteriorated and I feel violated.

Empiezas con una flecha la cual puedes atraer a ti y la habilidad de rodar, con eso iras descubriendo zonas con distintos jefes con un punto dÃ©bil pero no te lo darÃ¡n fÃ¡cil, activar botones, traerlos a lugares especÃ­ficos y tener un timing de locos. En cuanto a lore no es que haya mucho mas que unos murales, un Ãºnico jefe que te habla y el jefe final, de ahÃ­ conclusiones tuyas. 
En conclusiÃ³n, lo recomiendo comprarlo si esta en oferta ya que su precio es muy elevado para el tiempo de gameplay.
Titan souls es definitivamente un juego, que si te gustan los retos y los boss rush, al 100% deberÃ­as jugar, ya que este es todo un referente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100289647', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1680646751}
review:
A ideia do jogo Ã© interessante, o estilo de arte me atrai, mas contÃ©m diversos pontos que acabaram deixando a minha experiÃªncia negativa (derrotei 13 chefes no momento):

1- Boss-Fights majoritariamente 1hit-kill, para ambos os lados. VocÃª toma um hit = vocÃª morre; vocÃª acerta um hit = vocÃª mata. Isso deixa muito difÃ­cil de aprender a batalha e saber se o que estÃ¡ fazendo estÃ¡ certo ou errado. A ideia de 1hit-kill deixa que muitas lutas tenham uma Ãºnica mecÃ¢nica, deixando elas uni-dimensionais, alÃ©m de deixar a experiÃªncia frustrante (leva 1 hit = morre) e nada recompensadora. Todo Boss que matava eu nÃ£o me sentia recompensado por esse mesmo motivo: se eu acertava, eu matava; isso faz com que tu nÃ£o sinta que 'avance' em uma batalha por deixar o Boss com menos vida em uma tentativa do que outra. Ou vocÃª ganha, ou perde; nÃ£o tem meio termo.

2- Em conjunto com a frustraÃ§Ã£o de perder uma luta, a viagem do Checkpoint atÃ© a luta e o fade-out quando perde, faz com que vocÃª passe a maior parte do tempo caminhando do que lutando em si.

3- Ainda falando de caminhada. O jogo NÃƒO POSSUI mapa nem nenhuma forma de saber onde vocÃª estÃ¡, o que matou e/ou o que falta matar ou para onde ir (pelo menos atÃ© onde eu joguei nÃ£o achei nada disso). Passava um bom tempo passeando pelo mapa tentando encontrar onde deveria ir ou se estava seguindo o caminho certo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198833076753', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1680452784}
review:
O jogo Ã© curto (com o cÃ©rebro desligado eu levei 3h pra zerar) e num geral, bom

Todos os bosses sÃ£o puzzles, tem um ponto fraco que tu tem que acertar pra derrotar e a parte difÃ­cil Ã© resolver esse "puzzle" de como acertar. Ainda nÃ£o derrotei todos os bosses (deixei alguns pra trÃ¡s pq o jogo nÃ£o dÃ¡ uma direÃ§Ã£o, entÃ£o pensei que teria q voltar e derrotar eles posteriormente, Ã© intuitivo mas nÃ£o 100%) mas generalizando, os bosses sÃ£o bons com algumas exceÃ§Ãµes, como o penÃºltimo onde a dificuldade se dÃ¡ majoritariamente na hitbox dele sendo horrÃ­vel tanto pros lasers quanto pras mÃ£os. Num geral a dificuldade do jogo vem de vc tomar hitkill pra literalmente tudo (assim como muitos bosses) e eles terem mais recursos que vocÃª, alÃ©m da janela de ataque ser pequena e vocÃª ter que carregar a flecha pra atirar. Ã‰ sobre timing.
Outro ponto negativo que quero ressaltar Ã© a locomoÃ§Ã£o e respawn, a parte mais difÃ­cil do jogo Ã© a tortura de ter q andar alguns caminhos pra certos bosses, uma escolha meio esquisita de design que parece se inspirar em Souls, mas Souls mesmo no seu Ãºltimo lanÃ§amento (Elden Ring) tenta corrigir isso e diminuir a corrida por gauntlets e caminhos tortuosos. As rolagens nÃ£o sÃ£o Iframes e isso pode encher o saco em algumas horas, mas talvez comprometesse a dificuldade do jogo.

o ponto positivo Ã© tudo que eu nÃ£o critiquei aqui: os grÃ¡ficos e trilha sonora sÃ£o simples e impecÃ¡veis, a dificuldade do jogo Ã© recompensadora e num geral, nÃ£o Ã© tÃ£o desbalanceado, parece um teste de battle iq que se torna divertido conforme tu pega o jeito.

Apesar da morte ser na maioria das vezes inevitÃ¡vel, o jogo rapidamente te coloca de pÃ© de novo, evitando a frustraÃ§Ã£o que esse tipo de jogo geralmente propaga. O jogo tem uma duraÃ§Ã£o bem baixa, justificando seu baixo preÃ§o, contudo, seu tamanho nÃ£o Ã© algo ruim, jÃ¡ que evita de te deixar cansado do jogo e enjoar dele, sinceramente, o tamanho ta Ã³timo, principalmente quando vocÃª percebe que foi feito por uma equipe de 3 pessoas. author: {'steamid': '76561198050301254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1679866716}
review:
A really great commitment to a really bad idea.

All bosses kill you in one hit, but you also kill all bosses in one hit, so the entire point of the game is trying to find the opening or figure out the gimmick to hit the bosses weak point. Which sounds bad on paper already, but made worse that there is basically 0 content in this game except bosses. When finding an opening one time is enough to beat a boss, no boss is ever satisfying. There's never a moment where I'm low on hp, heart racing, almost to killing a boss I've been stuck on for an hour, because I'm always at one HP, and so is the boss. This means that the majority of play time you will be 
1. finding a boss in the world (which feels unjustifiably large for how little is actually in it
2. walking to the boss room from a checkpoint
3. trying to set up the opening against the boss
4. either missing and repeating steps 2 and 3, or landing the hit and repeating from step 1.

That's it. That's the whole game. Having a large number of bosses cannot act as a replacement for having good bosses, and you can't have good bosses when they all feel the same because they all die in one hit.

author: {'steamid': '76561199175290775', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1679694438}
review:
Buen primer juego de los creadores de Deaths Door, no puedo decir que no me divertÃ­ y me la pasÃ© bien derrotando jefes, pero por supuesto trae algunos problemas que estropean un poco la experiencia
.1.-Los checkpoints deberÃ­an estar justo en la batalla con el jefe, no tiene sentido que se trate de un boss rush y cuando te maten tengas que volver a recorrer cierto camino para volver a pelear.
2.-POR QUÃ‰ WEA NO TIENE MENÃš DE PAUSA, no tiene sentido tampoco, ni que fuera algÃºn juego online qpedo
3.-La mÃºsica de David Fenn es increÃ­ble, pero una vez que pierdes con el jefe se termina, lo cual es malardo teniendo en cuenta que no se logra apreciar del todo si es que pierdes o acabar con el jefe rÃ¡pidamente, lo cual hace que este punto estÃ© ligado con el primero y el de abajo tambiÃ©n
4.-Las pantallas de carga son algo largas para el juego que es, entenderÃ­a si fuera un AAA pero es un juego indie sobre matar bosses, lo cual termina pausando el ritmo de juego
5.-El mundo en general es algo largo para recorrer cuando estÃ¡ totalmente vacÃ­o salvo que algun que otro secreto o ruta.
6.-Los controles estÃ¡n bien pero a veces estÃ¡n algo incÃ³modos, agradecerÃ­a si hubiera algÃºn tipo de auto apuntado o asistencia con el ratÃ³n, ya que muchas veces estoy a punto de ganarle a un jefe pero el personaje no puede apuntar a ese lugar, es algo que saca de quicio, no se como explicarloY por Ãºltimo pero no menos importante, si bien es divertido pelear con tantos jefes, al final la mecÃ¡nica es casi siempre la misma, esperar a que hagan cierto movimiento y dispararle la flecha, sÃ© que por el estilo de juego no se puede permitir mucha variedad pero eso hace que se vuelvan predecibles los jefes, el jefe final igual es decepcionante y al final es mÃ¡s cuestiÃ³n de suerte y de timing que hace que las batallas terminen de forma abrupta y duren poco, y la habilidad termina pasando a un segundo plano.

review: It's not a long game, but it's a very rewarding game. You can probably beat it in one sitting. It's a game about fighting bosses and everyone has 1hp, including you. Once you beat the game, there's a harder new game+ mode, as well as achievements for every boss for doing certain things during the battle. It's a fun time and is a game I come back to play once every year or two, so it has at least a little bit of replay-ability.

review:
Este juego no es del todo malo pero tiene sus defectos que me dan la razÃ³n para darle una mala reseÃ±a.

En base a lo que he jugado hasta ahora de este juego puedo decir que tiene un dificultad artificial, convirtiendo jefes que podrÃ­an ser efÃ­meros pero frenÃ©tica la experiencia de enfrentarte a ellos porque quien da el primer golpe gana en tan solo patrones interminables con ataques pasivos y principales injustos hasta casi imposibles aun sabiendo que tu Ãºnica arma es una flecha mÃ¡gica que cuando la usas o la vas a recoger o la "llamas" para que vuelva a ti, ademas de contar con sistema de rodar muy trillado aparte de ni si quiera darnos alguna novedad o algo para poder variar un poco el estilo de combate sintiÃ©ndose repetitivo, monÃ³tono y aburrido al corto tiempo haciendo que no pueda disfrutar este juego como deberÃ­a sin ignorar la muy vaga por no decir nula personalizaciÃ³n de controles y muy pobre menÃº de opciones.

Los puntos a favor que tengo para destacar de este juego su banda sonora, encaja perfectamente en el mundo y espacio que se esta experimentado acompaÃ±ado de un diseÃ±o minimalista y simple pero que cumple con un nivel de bastante bueno para ser un juego indie salido el 2015 pero aun y con todo esto no termina de ser de mi agrado este juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561199445354115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1679173412}
review: This game doesn't respect your time. I got through the first gate at minute 40 going in blind. I went back and used a stop watch to see how much of my playtime was spent loading and back tracking. It came out 15 minutes out of a 40 minute play through. Once you get passed the first gate you have to travel WAY farther to reach the boss. I can't fathom how much time would be spent wasted walking in this game. Its not like traveling with the horse in shadow of the colossus or exploring an interesting castle like ico. Its walking around a boring hub world to get smashed in a couple seconds repeat. They wanted to pad out the games length by making you waste a bunch of time walking to the encounter. I have no doubt i could clear this game in under an hour if i could respawn immediately after dying. If you value your time i would avoid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016072630', 'num_games_owned': 1746, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1679159734}
review: I was looking forward for this game for a long time but I was very disappointed. There are no upgrades, just a few bosses and that's it. After beating the game you have some hard modes available. My biggest problem was not very fluent movement, kind of stiff. You cannot bind the keys, there are arrows and 2 keys you need and you can't bind it for some reason. I prefer keyboard and at the last boss I found out that keyboard has limited aiming for just 8 directions and you can't use the mouse. So even though I don't like aiming with the joystick I had to use it at least for the final boss. There should be also a possibility to restart the fights right away instead of having to run from a checkpoint. Overall the game isn't that bad, it is just shame that those few details are ruining the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198268082663', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1678992947}
review: I love challenging games, but I couldn't enjoy Titan Souls. The checkpoint system was extremely annoying. I felt like I did more walking back to bosses than actually fighting. With how unforgiving the bosses are, one hit and you're dead, you'd hope that the checkpoints would put you right back outside the boss. And I wish defeating the bosses felt exciting and rewarding, but the controls felt clunky and slow, and I got hardly any satisfaction from beating the bosses. I dropped this game more than halfway through, but perhaps one day I'll find the time to finish it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075194061', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1628467481}
review: You one shot bosses, bosses one shot you. Outside of the boss fights, you are mostly just exploring atmospheric landscapes and trying to piece together a very obtuse story, but in them you get to enjoy some great animation, generally pretty good fights and cool theming. I overall enjoy the game, but can only recommend it to people who love 2d games and boss fight focused games like Furi, Dark Souls and megaman simultaniously.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118339047', 'num_games_owned': 857, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1678999948}
review: Rediscovered this game after realizing it was made by the same dev team behind Death's Door. Truly a hidden gem that has been lost to time. Quick fun challenge that has the mission statement: What if you AND the monster only take one hit to kill. No one talks about this game which is a real shame. This title has some of the most unique battles and with simple but difficult to master mechanics. It's a cool af no hit boss fighting simulator, with a well designed world (purely in visuals, I'm sure there's a cool story here, but not my focus with this one) and beautiful music. And be warned. True challenge awaits you. Whether you prevail with skill, perseverance, or just blind luck. All feel great to achieve.P.S.  (get on sale it goes for like 2 bucks usually)

author: {'steamid': '76561198057728888', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1678761744}
review:
Interesting boss fights marred by uninteresting checkpoints.

I enjoy what this game does visually and mechanically as a soulslike game, but it also gets hindered by its strange map design.

As a boss rush game, the whole concept of one-touch one-kill is very exciting, you get only one chance to survive the fight, but most bosses also only take one good well-aimed arrow to be defeated. 

As such, this game should be enforcing that gameplay loop, but instead, the distance you have between checkpoints and boss fights very quickly cool down that short burst of excitement too much too often. 

In comparison to something like DS or elden ring or even Monster Hunter, the space between fainting and engaging the boss can often be used by the player to stock up on resources and prepare for the next try. However, this game doesn't have any resources for the player to make use of, due to its simplicity.

What you end up with is just a frustrating checkpoint system that does nothing but annoy you as backtrack the same route to engage with the one fun part of the game. 

I don't hate this game, I just dislike how it really disengages me really quickly, by the nature of said checkpoints.
